data.title: FILM: The Man from U.N.C.L.E
data.text:
The original TV show was much better. âThe Man from U.N.C.L.E.â aired from 1964-1968 and was extremely popular. I was 14 when Robert Vaughn, David McCallum, and Leo G. Carroll introduced the world to Napoleon Solo, IIlya Kuryakin and Alexander Waverly.

I get feisty just hearing the names of Napoleon Solo and Illya Kuryakin; two of the coolest fictional names ever. Iâm thinking about changing my name to Napoleon Harrison; no wait I meant Larry Solo. Ok, I got it: Larry Kuryakin. You can call me Larry K.

With that enthusiastic attitude and a historical background of 50 years, I entered Theatre #1 at The Fountains; yeah, the one with the reclining chairs, and I was ready to take a ride with the UNCLE characters currently played by Henry Cavill (Solo), Armie Hammer (Kuryakin), and Hugh Grant (Waverly). My money was on this movie to be a summer hit, and I was confident that it would surely take me back to my teen years with some fun and frolic.

I got a bad feeling with the opening scene; actually it was the music. It was just off. The opening scenes were truly some of the best of the movie, so my gusto increased and I began believing that Director and Co-writer Guy Ritchie was about to deliver a big pitch. A pitch worth 75 million bucks! Where did all that money go?

Well, most of it apparently went into the visual effects; this movie is beautifully produced and handsomely stylistic. Itâs classic Guy Ritchie. Oops, I temporarily forgot that Iâm not a big fan of Ritchie.

I liked it when he did something with Madonna (2009), but letâs not forget that Ritchie directed âSherlock Holmes,â also in 2009, starring Robert Downey Jr., Jude Law, and hottie Rachel McAdams. Ritchieâs take on Holmes was a flop; Iâve watched it more than once in an attempt to support three of my favorite actors. Close, but no banana. Hey, Guy, how do you mess up a movie about Sherlock freaking Holmes?

Holmes reminds me of this movie; decent plot -- secret agents from the US and Soviet Union working together in the early 1960âs to stop nuclear proliferation; great visuals and lofty subject matter, but kooky chemistry. Thatâs my new term for âbad movie; itâs the directorâs fault, and dang it.â

Iâm tired and I wanna go home. Rock ân Roll.

Grade 70. Larry H. www.larryhmoviereviews.com

U.N.C.L.E. -- United Network Command for Law and Enforcement
